title: Bergisel
text:
The Bergisel is a <a href="hill">hill</a> (746 m) that lies to the south of <a href="Innsbruck">Innsbruck</a>, <a href="Austria">Austria</a>, in the area of <a href="Wilten">Wilten</a>, where the <a href="Sill%20River">Sill river</a> meets the <a href="Inn%20River">Inn Valley</a>.
The word's first syllable "Berg-" doesn't correspond etymologically to the German word "Berg" with the meaning "mountain". The Bergisel's contemporary name is derived from the pre-Roman word "burgusinus" (elevated position), which then altered through <a href="folk%20etymology">folk etymology</a>, causing the occasional spelling "Berg Isel" or its English equivalent "Mount Isel".
Among its earlier uses were as a cremation site and as a habitation area during the Iron Age.
In 1809, Bergisel was the site of the four <a href="Battles%20of%20Bergisel">Battles of Bergisel</a> under the command of the <a href="freedom%20fighter">freedom fighter</a> <a href="Andreas%20Hofer">Andreas Hofer</a>. In 1892, the Andreas Hofer <a href="monument">monument</a> was erected in order to commemorate the battles.
Since 1952, Innsbruck has hosted one leg of the <a href="Four%20Hills%20Tournament">Four Hills Tournament</a>. The <a href="Bergiselschanze">Bergiselschanze</a> was built of <a href="concrete">concrete</a> for the <a href="1964%20Winter%20Olympics">1964 Winter Olympics</a> to replace an older, smaller ramp. It was also used for the <a href="1976%20Winter%20Olympics">1976 Winter Olympics</a>. A new ramp was opened in 2003, designed by the architect <a href="Zaha%20Hadid">Zaha Hadid</a>, as the old one no longer conformed to contemporary requirements of <a href="ski%20jumping">ski jumping</a>.
Until an accident following a mass panic, which resulted in several <a href="death">death</a>s, the Bergisel stadium was also the site of the <a href="Air%20%26amp%3B%20Style">Air & Style</a> <a href="snowboard">snowboard</a> festival.
Both the <a href="Brenner%20railway">Brenner railway</a> and the <a href="Brennerautobahn">Brennerautobahn</a> have tunnels below the Bergisel. The <a href="Sill%20Gorge">Sill Gorge</a>, a recreational site, is located at its base.
The Bergisel can be reached by the <a href="Stubaitalbahn">Stubaitalbahn</a> from <a href="Innsbruck">Innsbruck</a>, exiting at Station Sonnenburgerhof, or by the Tram 1, at Station Bergisel.
